advice_to_mgmt: Keep on improving.

pros: Great product. It works which makes it an easy sell, free lunches and great training make it a pleasure when getting started.
cons: There is a large hierarchy when starting out so don't expect a quick promo if you already have tons of experience. There is an extremely high turnover of staff.
advice_to_mgmt: More strategic career planning is recommended. Often managers discuss this with you and then leave and then more junior people get promoted to above you if even if more experience already in place

review_title: Terrific company, especially for new grads or sr managers
pros: Innovative, growing company with solid senior leadership and smart people overall. Typical tech perks like catered lunches and dinners, stocked kitchens, ping pong and pool tables, nap hammocks, etc.
cons: Limited opportunity for career advancement, below market base salaries in the Bay Area's absurdly expensive housing market. Great place for someone beginning their career or for senior managers, less so for those that have several years of experience but are not senior management level.
advice_to_mgmt: Invest more heavily in employee retention, creating clear career paths, spend some time speaking to and getting feedback from individual contributors.

pros: Internship program is well-managed - a few fun off-sites and good community among co-workers. Work component was excellent. Interns are provided with both a leader/mentor who oversees the project and a sort of "buddy" who provides day-to-day help and camaraderie. Internship was an excellent learning experience, as my mentor put a lot of effort into giving me an achievable but challenging product with real impact - something I could be proud of. Also, free food.
cons: Quantcast sports fairly decent facilities, but doesn't quite rival the absurdity (read: Odawalla smoothies - I'm looking at you, Google) of creature comforts that one might find at a big-name tech company. Overall, for a ~700-person company, I found the perks provided to be excellent.
advice_to_mgmt: Management does an excellent job of overseeing intern projects, and ensuring that interns can finish the summer having produced something of genuine value which has provided them with a learning experience.

pros:
Great benefits
Free lunch and snacks
Lots of talented, motivated employees
Company encourages employees to think outside of the box
cons:
Work hours can vary significantly
Typical growing pains of a startup-occasional turnover, large scale system changes

pros: Great people here. Product is pretty sophisticated. Not the most difficult sale and selling to marketing people is nice - they get it.
cons: Pay is very basic and incentives are lacking. "Moving Up" in the company isn't always a good thing here. Very little support for sales team from other parts of the company, and you don't get any Quantcast apparel which is frustrating.
advice_to_mgmt: Update the incentives and give the sales team more tools. Presidents club should be attainable by everyone and you should give the team the tools necessary to succeed and want to succeed.

pros: Working with some of the most brilliant people in the world. Get to work on some most exciting technologies that are not open to the rest of the world.
cons: San Francisco office is in SOMA. Housing is ridiculously expensive around the office.

pros:
Rapidly growing company with a never ending list of new and interesting challenges. T
here's really no other competitor with the amount of data Quantcast has collected and arguably no one who can offer the same full funnel approach in the digital advertising space.
Great environment with pool tables, ping pong, bike storage, catered lunches and dinners and flexibility to get your work done in your own style.
cons: New challenges can often mean longer hours.

pros: Great people, innovative products backed by solid data.
cons: Company does not provide 401K matching

review_title: Great Company Name, Commoditized Adtech Business Model
pros: Known entity in the space, due to their audience measurement product. Good name recognition and known to be one of the biggest 'data' players in the space.
cons: Business Model is being an ad network. Performance is not always better than competitors (even though supposedly it should be from data set). Also many publishers taking down their Quantcast pixels due to them being non-neutral anymore, and also most of their 100M 'tags' are from wordpress.
advice_to_mgmt: Clean up your sales team, reduce the burn rate

review_title: Young company, good place to work
pros: Great perks like happy hour and lunch
cons: Management is sub par, restrictions on growth, lower salaries than average
advice_to_mgmt: Work on employee retention

pros: Smart people, nice culture and lots of perks!
cons: Management tends to focus too much on long-term.

pros: Excellent product in the marketplace and positioned well for growth in the adtech space. Also pre-IPO and looking to go public in the 1-2 year range. Plenty of free food for lunch and dinner and snacks when you need them. Culture is great and the sales team is a fun-loving group that is very hard working. The training and support is dedicated and ongoing and really sets Quantcast apart when you look at similar companies. Good opportunities to expand your role and take on leadership roles or find new opportunities as you advance. Current leadership is a dedicated group with vision
cons:
Below average salary for the market and San Francisco itself. There is some balance when factoring in total compensation, but don't expect the base (or initial base + bonus) to blow you away. They are strong at recognizing and rewarding hard work and achievement, but in between these periods there is limited opportunity to "blow your number away" and pull in a large bonus

At the current moment, there is also no 401k matching, gym benefit or commuter stipend

review_title: Great start-up vibe and great people to be around
pros: Excellent technology built from the ground up. Great perks and wonderful people to be around.
cons: Not much I can think of.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the excellent work!

review_title: Good But Lacking Competencies Required For Greatness
pros:
Fun, happy work environment in exciting industry.

Filled with a lot of great people and personalities.

Product is excellent. Great reputation. Major adtech player with a very bright future.

CEO amongst other executives lead by example and are respected.

In general, it's a great place to work.
cons:
Lack of authority and accountability:

We reward people that go beyond what's asked of them. We reward people for good, positive behavior, however, when it comes to people NOT doing their job, NOT doing what's asked or expected of them and NOT acting appropriately, there is a complete lack of consequences and accountability.

Example: Leadership asks the entire organization to use a tool to communicate. Only half the people use it and the rest disregard request with no repercussion or worry of authority.

Lack of communication:

We under-communicate, both across departments and vertically. The channels to communicate aren't defined along as are the expectations as to who should be communicating. Everything, whether we added a new executive to the team, added a new feature to the product, or announced a major partnership is under-communicated from top to bottom and side to side. Leads to a whole lot of confusion, miscommunication and hearsay.

Example: Major partnership formed or key executive joins/leaves company with little to no announcement made to the entire organization either via email or another means.
advice_to_mgmt: Ask more of your employees. Communicate more with your employees. Lay down the law.

pros: Strong leadership & role models who challenge and motivate. Exciting company, growing quickly.
cons: Work life balance & benefits could use some additional focus.

pros:
- Great product that consistently performs and drives value for customers
- Massive data set is a huge competitive advantage
- Good people are who intelligent and great to work with
- Fun culture - people LIKE to stay late and get work done (free dinner doesn't hurt there either)
- Great perks
cons:
- Not enough customer support resources
- Unclear company mission and values
- Product Management is far too disconnected from sales and client services.
- Weak marketing presence
- Inconsistent career pathing
advice_to_mgmt: What's the reason Quantcast exists? Over-communicate the company goals and values (qualitative, not just we need to do $X in revenue). Leadership should have a clear message to the company so all employees are looking in the same direction. Imbalance in emphasis between Measure (non-paid product) and Advertise (paid) leads to confusion in the market - company message and marketing needs to align better with Advertise. Quantcast should be a power player in adtech above lesser products from DMP's and DSP's but it doesn't yet carry the weight that it should. Sales needs a global leadership presence.

review_title: Decent technology company, but you'll probably be happier elsewhere.
pros:
Good location, great social work environment. All the engineers that work there love to hang out and drink together. They have pool tables and ping-pong. There is decent catered lunch and dinner.

The technology is cutting edge. There are a lot of challenges to solve.
cons: The industry is terrible. There is little likelihood that the stock will be worth much. There is very little opportunity for growth professionally. The office is filthy, if you interview there, make sure you get them to take you on a walk around the floor. Also, they only show people the 8th floor when interviewing, which is nicer than the other floor.
advice_to_mgmt: Put more work into training and mentoring existing employees.

review_title: Fast Paced Growth, Things are Changing.
pros:
- high energy environment
- plenty of challenging projects
- great location
cons: - recently some new senior leaders have come on board. they do not seem interested in getting around and speaking to the individual contributor level employees. when you see them in the hallways they look down or start working on their cell phone. it was not always this way!
advice_to_mgmt: Get around the office more and speak to the individual contributors. Or at least say hello to people when you see them in the hallways. If you don't know their name, ask them. It feels like senior management is only speaking to other senior management ... does not bode well for QC.

review_title: Great Company That has an awesome reputation in the space
pros:
- Love the people, perks and mix of clients you can work with
- Advertising comes with having pride for the brands and clients your represent and that definitely happens here
- Fun events and beer cart, nice seeing the CEO on the floor and events involved with others
- Ability to sit down with an executive, director and head and get 1 on 1 time is amazing
cons: - Cant hire quality people fast enough
advice_to_mgmt: None

pros: Great in-office perks, great work/life balance, expectations are clear and very reasonable, great environment, great employees. Best of all, the energy of the company and it's employees is incredible.
cons: No cons and I believe the majority of employees here would agree with me.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep of the great work! Your work-ethic, excitement and overall positivity is great for the company and employees.

review_title: Great combination of nice workplace, hot industry and good upside
pros:
The culture encourages innovation through elaborate hackathons and recognition.
Good SWE technical level.
RTB is interesting and hot. Quantcast is positioned well with good ML and big data tech.
Good amount of internal promotions to leadership positions.
The environment is somewhat similar to Google, energetic and dynamic. A number of Quantcast employees came from Google, a number of former Quantcast employees are now at Google.
cons: There is pressure and stress from strong competition in the Adtech space. RTB is a 24x7 business and the technology is fairly new and evolving quickly. It can get a bit intense.

review_title: This is the best company I've ever worked for.
pros: Hats off to Konrad, who built a spectacular Team from top to bottom. I wish that other companies, big or small, will follow your example. This is the future.
cons: I tried to think of a negative comment but could not come up with anything. Of course no company is perfect. There are always some flaws and loose ends. But, these shortcomings are so insignificant that's not even worth mentioning.
advice_to_mgmt: Don't ever change the management style. But always keep an eye of ineffective and horrible bosses. These people will ruin what you've started.

review_title: Great opportunity to be at the forefront of big data and work for a company with a great culture!
pros: Everyone you work with is extremely humble but are among the best and brightest in their individual fields. The senior leadership cultivates a people first culture and focuses on people and product.
cons: Nothing - I love it
advice_to_mgmt: Keep doing what you are doing! It is fantastic to be apart of such a great company and have a product that is a leader in digital advertising.

pros: Great people to work with every day, very invested in sales people with tons of sales training from good peple, sales culture is pretty typical of any start up - ABC!
cons: Pay is not at par with other tech companies, sales leadership leaves a lot to be desired
advice_to_mgmt: the constant switching to different KPI's every quarter leads people to believe you don't know what you're doing

pros: Culture of company is warm and supportive while still being entrepreneurial with a lot of opportunities to make an impact through side projects or new initiatives.
cons: Clear schism between operations and R&D, but that is resolving itself over time with management initiatives.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep it up!

review_title: Quantcast is the best place I have ever worked at, hands down.
pros:
- Solid, differentiated product that enables advertisers to achieve their marketing objectives and find their best prospects at scale
- Compensation is fair, the benefits are awesome and the perks are beyond generous (free lunch and dinner, snacks all day, weekly happy hour with food and drinks, holiday parties, pool and ping pong tables etc)
- Supportive managers and collaborative teams make work rewarding and fulfilling
- Excellent training when you start and a consistent emphasis on learning and growth
- Amazing, smart, interesting people abound
- Exciting future as the company grows globally
cons: - No matching for 401K contributions
advice_to_mgmt: Keep doing what your doing!

pros: A great place to work at. A lot of opportunities to grow and contribute, and a lot of challenging work on a day-to-day basis. Smart and pleasant people around.
cons: The company grew at the rapid rate and there's a bit of uncertainty in the company goals and directions, as well as a lack of clearly defined roles.
advice_to_mgmt: Pay more attention to the career goals of employees.

review_title: Benefits and pay are great but the company is very disorganized
pros:
-Free breakfast, lunch, and dinner
-Cell phone bill is paid for
-Happy hour every Friday
-Very smart and motivated team members
-Quantcast is a "sleeping giant" and on the path to success
cons:
- No concern for employee training and development
- Micro-managed work environment
- Late hours with little to no recognition
- No accountability- everyone is quick to point the finger at other teams when something goes wrong
advice_to_mgmt: Everyone is working towards the same goal - Don't forget we are all on the same team.

pros:
-Positive and encouraging work environment
-Ability to make change happen and see the impact
-If you're up for the challenge, there's so much to learn
-I'm proud to work for Konrad
-Mmmm lunch and snacks!
cons:
-Moves quickly, which is great, until you're overworked and under-resourced
-Things aren't always transparent, and inside knowledge is container to a small, select circle
-HR is pretty old school, and prioritizes paperwork over innovative benefits and career development found in most tech firms
advice_to_mgmt:
-Invest in T&D for people BESIDES sales people
-Pick up your heels on hiring our C-level staff please. People feel directionless

review_title: People are GREAT! Executive Management is Meh
pros: Almost everyone who works here is smart, friendly and fun! I can actually say I love my co-workers.
cons: Upper management and middle management seems all over the place. Some of them are strategic and some of them totally suck and should have been fired months ago.
advice_to_mgmt: Stop hiring so quickly, stop creating all of these management layers, there are too many cooks in the kitchen right now.

pros:
- Free food: breakfast, lunch, and dinner, drinks & snacks, beer carts & happy hour food
- Pool and ping pong table
cons:
- Lack of engineering resources, always hard to get projects prioritized unless it's a top "priority", but I guess that happens at every company
- Micro-management (depends which department you work in)
- Lack of career growth

pros: Strong product, Strong Vision, Good training, Crowded space but they are in the process of changing the voice of the brand, tremendous upside and opportunity with the product and offering, the company will be successful....
cons: Horrible work environment, Lots of people looking busy but not doing much, focused on company interest, not client interest, weak mobile product
advice_to_mgmt: listen to your clients, focus on revenue drivers and members that are in the field

review_title: Quantcast has been a terrific ride!
pros: If you do well, you get promoted relatively quickly. There are lots of new initiatives for you spearhead and establish yourself amongst your coworkers.
cons: Things move fast and can get chaotic. If you get anxiety from "not knowing what to do," this isn't the place for you.
advice_to_mgmt: Share more about the long term vision for the company. I feel that a disruptive shift needs to take place for us to become a billion dollar company. What would that look like?

review_title: Great culture but is it too large already?
pros:
Lots of fun events. Really easy to get to know people here. Flat hierarchy. If you have an idea, you can go out and do it. Management cares a lot about keeping people happy and it shows.

Konrad and his senior management team are amazingly talented and caring people. I would not bet against them.
cons:
Be wary of the reviews you see here. They explicitly ask their employees to review them on Glassdoor so the reviews are likely biased.

The culture of the sales team is exerting a stronger and stronger influence on the culture of the company as a whole. This may be a good thing or bad thing depending on where you sit.

Company is growing fast so you may be placed under a mediocre to bad line manager who has little experience managing people.
advice_to_mgmt: Make sure the sales team culture does not dominate the entire company's culture.

review_title: Quantcast is an ok place to sork
pros: It is an average place to work
cons: They are a total disorganized mess

review_title: Great people, great culture, interesting problems, and a bright future.
pros: The scale we deal with is mind boggling and that makes otherwise simple problems require innovation. Every engineer has the opportunity to design and implement a lot of fun pieces of software. Employees are generally all A-players in their domain and extremely technical.
cons: the rtb world is extremely fast paced and the company moves at breakneck speed, so if you are the kind of developer who likes a nice stree-free 9-5 work week this isn't the place.

pros: Intelligent, hard-working, fun, motivated, cool, and attractive people. Free breakfast, lunch, and dinner. Minimal pointless meetings
cons: Office is too small, not enough meeting rooms

review_title: Lots of work, no recognition, and zero work-life balance
pros:
Free food (this is used to tie you to your desk for 10 hours).
Great introduction into the programmatic space.
Friday afternoon beer cart.
cons:
You will be required to work from at least 8-6 every day. If you leave before 6pm, you get stares of death from everyone around.
You can hear a needle drop most days in the office and "fun" really isn't permitted. They love to pretend like everyone has fun, but as soon as you do it's seen as "goofing off".
The interview process was absurd - throughout they will compare themselves to Google and after a gauntlet of phone interviews, they will bring you in for a 4-6 hour day interview where you will meet with at least 4-6 different people. They will then five you a taxing "homework assignment" that they will expect you to complete by the next day (i.e. stay up all night after your current day job to complete). If they like you, they will then give you an exam of some kind and have you come back in to give a presentation.
Very little room to be yourself and have a personality. If you have weekly commitments outside of work, get ready to miss them. Your manager will complain to their bosses that you are not a "team player" and you'll most likely be reprimanded and/or fired.
advice_to_mgmt: This isn't rocket science and we aren't saving the world. It's advertising and selling squares on the internet. Please loosen up your grip a bit and embrace your employees. You expect the world from your employees but don't give them room to breathe or instill confidence. The office feels like a prison rather than a world of collaboration. If you want to be like Google (as many of the leaders say), then embrace quirkiness, don't be afraid to have fun, and don't expect humans to be robots.

review_title: Great place to work for as Software Engineer!
pros:
* Great Culture
- Lots of smart people
- Management does recognize individual contribution

* Technology
- Interesting technical problems to be solved!
- Lots of cool technologies and a wide range of languages being used in production, such as Java, Python and Go
- Encourage cross-functional movement

* Compensation
- Good salary, bonus and stock options
- Good perks

* Overall
- Company is doing great financially
- Company is growing rapidly

* Fun
- Best Ping Pong team among San Francisco Tech Companies
cons: Cannot think of any at the moment

review_title: Challenged every day, motivated by the talent and rewarded by management with growth and salary.
pros: Great collaboration between really intelligent people, empowered to make a change, resources (albeit limited at times) to make those changes, excellent culture, great vision by executive team, overall really rewarding to be a part of this successful start up.
cons: Always changing industry and technology is great but exhausting.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue to invest in hiring people and rewarding those that contribute so greatly to the company. Whether by public or private recognition, salary increase or other perks.

review_title: Great Company. Brightest people in the industry. Engineering Centric. Lacking in communication structure & management.
pros: Great perks. The brightest people in the industry you'll get to work with. Great technology company with strong products. A lot of exciting changes as the company is going through an aggressive growth stage. Very generous with benefits and comps.
cons: The company is going through a hyper growth stage and is too heavily sales driven. Loosing some of its cultural identity or defining it and becoming a bit too corporate. Poor/immature mid-management team. Very silo communications or transparency between department. HR department growth is lacking and is very much behind company's growth.
advice_to_mgmt: Focus more on developing your management team and ensuring they're better equip for success.

pros: I've been at Quantcast just over a year and can say with confidence this company is doing the right thing. They are thought leaders taking a marathon approach to RTB vs. most players in the space who just sprint to the next easy dollar.
cons: As a growing company, Quantcast has some room for improvement in some basic benefits - 401K match, maternity/paternity leave, etc. If they were to fine tune these, it would put them over the top. These are basics at most tech companies in the Bay Area.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue to be transparent and open with employees. It's great to feel confident in the vision of the company and feel empowered to shape our future

pros:
The smartest people I've ever worked with from places like Google, Cisco, NASA.... You know, the scrub companies. Ha!
The best benefits you could ask for.
Amazing product and reputation for the product actually working!!!
Encourage innovation.
They give back to the community.
Catered breakfasts, lunches, dinners.
Everyone is SOOOOOO freaking nice!
cons: Nothing comes to mind no matter how hard I try. I have a 20 word minimum, so I'll say they could stop being so awesome? LOL
advice_to_mgmt: Keep doing exactly what you're doing!

pros: The people are a lot of fun and the work is very interesting. I've learned an incredible amount there, and feel like I'm meaningfully contributing to the products. The scale of the problems you get to tackle are enormous, and you can quickly get complete ownership over the development of major features. The food is good, and it's fairly easy to maintain a good work-life balance.
cons: It's online advertising, you're not exactly curing cancer.
advice_to_mgmt: Match charitable contributions. It'd be great to have more opportunities to give back.

review_title: Great culture, disruptive technology, fun place to work and grow your career.
pros:
* Smart people (even the non-engineers are pretty smart) who are also nice. Very little toxicity beyond standard communication challenges.
* Great leadership who are committed to building a long term company and exceptional value in the marketplace.
* Excellent culture - strong emphasis on training & development, catered lunches/dinners, ping-pong/foos/pinball/pool, beer brewing competition, beer cart Fridays, annual competition to present new ideas to senior executives (and win $$ and stock options), good benefits.
* Pre-IPO stage with every opportunity to contribute to the growth of a company that is creating serious disruption in a 100+ yr old industry.
cons:
* With a collaborative and "nice" startup culture comes communication issues (passive-aggressiveness, unresolved conflict) and over-reliance on consensus (which can lead to death by meeting).
* Startup related issues: some cross-departmental relationships could be better, career development paths could be more clear.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the good work! Maintain a focus on creating a thriving culture of excellence and hiring great people.

pros: Great products that work, proprietary data sets that differentiate the company from the noise in the marketplace. Intelligent team members across the board. World class training for the entire organization (sales training is comprehensive and like nothing I have ever seen at other companies). Great career growth potential in an exciting and breakout industry.
cons: Normal challenges in a hyper-growth environment. Adding A LOT of new people each month which is not a con, just creates challenges of integration and getting people up to speed.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue to invest in high caliber training. The transparency and leadership is refreshing and appreciated.

review_title: Joining Quantcast was one of my better decisions.
pros:
Frightfully smart people work here, but they do so with far less attitude than usually accompanies that. The quality of the people who work here, professionally and personally, is one of the things that makes me look forward to going into work each day. The people are not just smart people, they're good people.

The technical challenges are considerable. There are a lot of tricky problems to solve here. This is very cool.

The management is clearly trying to build a long-running concern (not a pump-and-dump startup), with constant attention to continually improving how they do business. The management appears genuinely concerned about providing ongoing career growth (and rewarding it). This is a more "grown-up" start up than many: with much of the playfulness, but less of the actual insanity I've noted so much of elsewhere.

I love the catered lunch--not just for the nutritious, mostly yummy food, but for the easy opportunity to socialize with clever, funny, friendly people.
cons:
The growing population of employees means you may need to wait for the bathroom. ;)

The usual growing pains associated with a start-up, including hiccups when balancing cost-control and expansion, or when scaling organizational structures as the company grows. I do think we're mostly doing a good job here.

Sometimes the workload is a bit much (see: "start-up"), but we are trying to hire....

There could be more transparency about the organizational structure. It can be hard to figure out what group works on what and where to find them.

We make money in marketing, which is less cool than making money in building solar panels or curing cancer.
advice_to_mgmt: The increased transparency is appreciated. Also, thanks for helping make this a company I enjoy working for!

review_title: Engineering culture, smart, ethical and cutting edge.
pros: Great products, fun culture and always looking for ways to innovate. Lots of smart people and opportunity for those looking to learn about adtech and grow their career. Quantcast is unique in that it captures first party data in real time to build complex targeting models rather than leverage third party data like most competitors do in this space. Work hard, play hard. We build great products and services around them.
cons: A little conservative for your typical start up culture. Not overly communicative on long term strategy or financial numbers.
advice_to_mgmt: Company information should be shared more freely...

review_title: Good career growth opportunities but a very high-strung workplace
pros: Quantcast tries to recognize your achievements, and even more, if you are engineers. So far, Quantcast seems receptive to employees’ feedback. It has a learning culture which is a great environment to be exposed to many different things for the curious mind.
cons: There is a lack in sense of accountability. The observed tendency is to try to assign blame to someone when things go wrong. This attitude brews buried unhealthy hostility toward people you work with. Another con is that if you are non-engineers, you do feel like second-class citizens a lot of the times.
advice_to_mgmt: Encourage a more open and respectful communication. Encourage more accountability amongst team members.

review_title: Great technology, not so great management.
pros: The technology stack is impressive. As an engineer you will work with some leading edge technology and some brilliant people. The Friday beer bash is impressive. Catered lunch and dinner if you stay past 7PM is also good. Nice offices (open floor plan). Good location, easy to commute to. Excellent place for recent grads as the pay scale is a bit low for the region. Extremely engineering centric which is good for engineers, not so great for everybody else. Not really a sweat shop; I saw very few engineers in on Saturday or Sunday.
cons: Antiquated management. No concern for career development. Limited communication downwards. Lot's of attention paid to acquiring new talent, very little paid to retaining existing talent. Company is too large now for new hires to make anything off stock options if the company ever goes public. This is a typical 'negative feedback' company. You will not get positive feedback when you do a good job but you will get negative feedback when you do a poor job. Communication between departments almost non-existent.
advice_to_mgmt: Advanced degrees don't always translate to productive employees or good managers. Develop a career growth path for new employees so they can have realistic, mutually beneficial goals with the organization. Improve the almost non-existent project management function and empower product managers who it seems are always under the thumb of engineering (which is somewhat backwards).

review_title: Do not join unless you're an engineer. You will be set up for failure.
pros: Great product! Free food, dinner and weekly happy hour. Nice office location. Pretty much it stops there.
cons: Lack of leadership and management is a mess. Long daily hours and weekends. No work life balance at all and lack of support from managers. There is no professional with other department. Sales, finance and CS team is a mess. There is no support with other department but mostly the blame game. There is a huge lack of corporate processes which should be consistence, effective, accuracy and timely. Everything is manual and pretty much broken. I was trained to email Sales and Finance and just wait for something to happen. It's a black-hole because I am constantly not meeting my client's request and target due to others delay action. Making it impossible to build new or retain client relations. It was a dead end place for me.
advice_to_mgmt: Pay attention to your Sales team and get them up to speed with company policy and procedure. Train sales, CS and AM how to properly launch their campaigns and meet client expectation. Consider automation for your accounting system/processes. There is no way you can file for S-1 when your internal info structure is broken.

review_title: Great company, although better when I joined
pros:
Working with really smart people around.
I've worked for couple of good software companies before. So far the experience here is the best indeed.
Some pioneer work on big data. Good reputation in big data community (at least I think).
I left for some personal reasons. Missed it.
cons: Sometimes feel management decisions unpredictable like black boxes. Long hours of working for some teams.

employee_title: Account Executive, Agency and Marketer Development
pros: Great office, catered meals, collaborative work space with brilliant minds, tremendous growth potential
cons: I have none to date

pros: strong product/solution, bright people, positive culture, highly engaged exec team & CEO
cons: in a strong tech/ ad market retaining talented employees can be a challenge

review_title: In a crowded and noisy space, Quantcast does things the right way and will pull away from the competition.
pros: An opportunity to learn and be in the middle of the most exciting industry in the world. You'll work on projects and accounts that truely mean something to not only the company but the overall ad tech space.
cons: Company growing fast, many tenured employees leaving once they're fully vested. Althought that's common in the startup world, hopefully management finds ways to retain folks that are loyal.
advice_to_mgmt: Management seems to really favor past Google employees and executives. It might be time to branch out and bring some different perspective to the company.

pros: Great culture and growing company
cons: i have no cons right now

pros: Lunches were nice, people were cool to talk to.
cons: Not as amazing as they think they are.
advice_to_mgmt: Company seems like it's only up to 5 people where the company goes. Makes an effort in general, but broader unity within company would be nice. Seemed like the departments thought the other departments were a pain to deal with.

review_title: Execs seem to firmly believe the injudicious philosophy that whatever Google did/does is the right choice for Quantcast.
pros:
Recruiting team has done a great job overall creating a great group of smart, fun and funny people who work well together. The corporate culture used to be best I had ever been lucky enough to be involved with.
Overall benefits are competitive.
If you ever worked at Google you will find it easy to get a job here and the execs will hang on your every word as if you were personally responsible for Google's success.
cons:
Exec team is short-sighted and one is driven so exclusively by his ego that it has caused the rapid unraveling the fabric of the formerly amazing corporate culture.
The execs appear to believe that the path to success is in following whatever footsteps Google made regardless of the circumstances.
Execs worship the engineers and all other teams are understaffed, overworked, underpaid and considered unimportant therefore not listened to.
advice_to_mgmt: Clean house...get rid of the scourge that is destroying the culture. Stop hiring engineers and start hiring people to support the customers and the necessary evils of administration.

pros: Quantcast is comprised of great people and great culture. Lots of off sites and company events. Lots of opportunity to explore side projects.
cons: Salary (for my position at least) could have been better, and raises were less than satisfactory. Catered food could have been better

review_title: Great product, but if you're not on the engineering team, you get no love
pros:
lots of smart, engaged co-workers
lots of perks: free lunch and dinner, good snacks, happy hours, team outings
great location near W hotel downtown
impressive technology and infrastructure
cons:
heavy bias towards engineering, with little to no resources for operations and client facing roles
lots of egos on the executive team with decisions being made in a vacuum
they do the difficult things well, and the easy things badly
not as cutting edge as they think
advice_to_mgmt:
Just because an engineer didn't build it doesn't mean it's worthless
Start paying attention to the people actually doing the work instead of the ones talking about the work

review_title: A great place to build a career
pros: The people are sharp and focused on getting things done well. Advertising technology is great field to work in. It's evolving fast and provides a river of fresh and interesting problems to solve, both technical and otherwise. You can be part of the reinvention of a $500B industry. Quantcast is small enough yet important enough that what you do really matters.
cons: Expect to pull your weight. The team works hard, supports each other, and gets a lot done. You can succeed through inspiration, perspiration or a mix of the two, but if you're used to a relaxed pace of meetings-about-meetings, it may not be right for you.

review_title: Exciting, challenging and rewarding experience at a progressive technology company.
pros: Smart people, great technology, advancing advertising.
cons: Great company, no complaints here.
advice_to_mgmt: More resources are needed to grow the infrastructure.

review_title: Fast Paced, incredibly informative, great training
pros: Overall company culture is outstanding.
cons: Sales department treated poorly and regarded as second class citizens in an engineering company. Salary is far below industry standards in digital media. High turnover - cannot maintain successful senior reps.

pros: I have worked at Quantcast for over a year now, and am extremely pleased with my experience here. On the sales team, we are led by managers who have a wealth of knowledge in the industry and are very supportive of personsal growth and development. We also have three full time trainers that lead weekly sessions on sales tactics. Beyond impressive management and growth, the people are Quantcast are one of the best assets. For a sales team, it is not a cut-throat environment. You are motivated by the people around you, who are smart and hard working, to do your best.
cons: There is definitely a "ramp up" period for this role. I came in with no sales or industry background, and it took a good 3-6 months to get a grasp on the sales cycle (it is long and heavy on education) and to start exceeding quota. Once you understand the process however, you come to enjoy the educational and relationship building piece that goes with such a young, fast-paced growing and changing industry. The ramp up period forced me to develop sales skills that will be transferrable to whatever career I end up in the future.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue to be transparent around promotional and pay raise opportunities.

review_title: Fast-growing and exciting place to work
pros:
Dynamic company in a dynamic industry
Hires the best of the best: bright and friendly coworkers
Industry-leading technology
cons: Not a small company anymore, but not yet a large company, it is to be seen how we will handle this delicate transition

review_title: Amazing product, very smart and focused team, incredible organization
pros: Certainly the smartest people I have ever worked with. This is a company focused on growing, disrupting, and changing the digital ad landscape. Incredibly fun culture with the right amount of work/life balance.
cons: Fast pace, figure it out as we grow technology start up. Things are changing, evolving, growing developing and will continue to do so for the quite some time. If that is exciting, and you work well with moving targets and and evolving workforce and infrastructure then you will thrive. If change is scary, or you need a manual for everything you do this will not be a good fit.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue to look forward, hire great people and stay committed to the model.

pros: Hard working team, challenging and interesting technology.
cons: Startup with a lot of new managers.

review_title: Do not join the Sales Team
pros: Awesome company (especially if you're an Engineer). Intelligent, fun, and supportive co-workers. Catered lunches, dinners and happy hours. All the perks of a start up.
cons: Horrible sales management (some of the managers are literally demeaning and verbally abusive), impossible goals to meet, everyone is paranoid that they will be let go due to not meeting goals (more so than normal sales departments), very hard to close sales (they are also hiring more and more people- so the list of accounts to reach out to is smaller and smaller daily), whether cold calling works or not- you are required to make 30 cold calls a day, and x amount of pitches, and x amount of emails.

review_title: The smartest people I've ever worked with
pros: Brilliant minds, youthful energy, professional people. Each organization within the company builds top-notch programs. Completely trust the executive leadership's vision.
cons: Growing fast, so quickly running out of room, but expanding into new space soon.
advice_to_mgmt: It would be wise to encourage healthy work / life balance year-round to ensure sustained results and consistent loyalty when short-term initiatives require longer hours and more energy.

review_title: Lots of interesting work. Great people. Some management issues.
pros:
- If you are in one of the engineering teams you'll be working with really smart people. The hiring bar is quite high. Overall, the coworkers are great and like to have fun.
- Interesting problems to work on. They will keep you motivated.
- Generally, the technical leads will give you lot of freedom in your work and are very open to suggestions.
- Quantcast is an ideal place for young straight out-of-school engineers.
- Delicious catered food. Happy hour. Beer carts.
- The company is growing and doing very well.
- Konrad (CEO) is a smart guy and does great work.
cons:
- Management communication style is very closed.
- Some teams have broad and undefined set of responsibilities. They lack focus. Makes working chaotic.
- A few teams are over-worked and have high attrition rates. One of the ways management tries to solve this problem is by offering a monthly cash award which is rotated among members of all teams. It does very little to solve the underlying issues.
- Considerable amont of technical debt. Management needs to address this concern.
- Management does not do enough to gain feedback from employees. Non existent 1:1 meetings with managers. Not enough importance is given to career development.
- Compensation is lower than market standards. Promotions are hard to come by. Quantcast has a very good referral policy rewarding successful referrals with multiple thousand dollars. But management does not feel it is necessary to offer promotions with similar rewards.
advice_to_mgmt: Be proactive with regards to employee feedback.

review_title: Great place to grow your career by throwin' yourself right into it!
pros:
Lunch & Dinner catered (its a great perk if you don't focus on why they actual provide this perk)
Great place Great place to figure out what your bottom line is around the number of hours you're expected to put in regularly.
Employers will value your experience here!
cons:
Expect 60+ hour weeks
Finance is a joke.
Poor HR representation
advice_to_mgmt: Invest in solid HR leadership & accountability. Promote & be pro-active in keeping employees informed of their healthcare info. They work very long hours for you. Take better care of them. It will cost you less in the end with less turn over.

pros: The only pro is if you are on the engineering team - then you are treated like gold. Plus you can always get a better job after Quantcast - new employers love it!
cons: The cons are purely against being in the sales department. It is ran horribly. You are treated like a drone. There are minimum cold calls and emails per day. There is no encouragement and only putting the team down. People are pushed to eat at their desks and to work 12hr days for little to no money. When you walk on the sales floor you will know that everyone is unhappy.
advice_to_mgmt: Figure out how to run a productive and happy team!

review_title: Great company, incredibly difficult to break new business
pros:
good start up culture
smart co workers
extensive training
good comp and great benefits
cons: company is expanding too fast, too hard to break and retain new business in a saturated market. Many reps not making goal and/ or commission. Free-for-all with no territory or verticals.

pros:
1. Extremely smart group of engineers who deliver results and know how to have fun
2. Management is open to suggestions and new ideas, transparency has been getting better and better
3. It feels like a family, people are very connected across all departments
4. Ridiculous lunch cater who is creative and BBQed a whole pig the other day for Euro Cup
cons:
Office space is getting very crowded, hopefully it will be addressed by the new space they got.
Since the office is wide open, it can be noisy and hard to concentrate sometimes.
Meeting rooms are not sound proof, and you can hear people talking during meeting from outside

pros:
- Bright group of folks in all departments company wide
- Cool technology stack
- Fun place to work, great location downtown
- Good perks. Good parties. Good people
cons:
- Long hours, if you're in Engineering or IT. Be prepared to work 60 hour weeks.
- Continuous tight deadlines means it's always crunch time
- Some groups seem to have things together as a team, while others struggle at times due to fundamentals that management just chooses to ignore.
advice_to_mgmt: Listen to your team, they won't steer you wrong.

review_title: Smart people, fun place to work.
pros: Quantcast does a great job of hiring smart people. Almost everyone who works there, including managment is highly technical. There's a real focus on getting things done without a lot of bureaucratic overhead. Conventional wisdom is always questioned, and using the "industry standard" solution for anything requires making a case that it's still the best way.
cons: Open plan work environment is noisy and distracting.

review_title: Amazing opportunity to contribute to interesting problems with awesome people
pros:
1) Cutting edge everything - you can get practical experience in real-time processing, filesystems, hadoop, etc
2) Awesome people
3) Good culture- chill but hardworking
4) Easy to move around if you wish to join a different team
5) Great perks - catered lunch and dinner
6) Great location
cons:
1) For some people it might be a bit too corporate, by which I mean it is not a tiny startup anymore and there do need to be some 'processes' which is deadly for those who like zero constraints on commits, etc that you might get at a small startup

2) I think people can be a little too focused on compensation as a reason to work and put in extra effort. That sounds naive, but in some places the internal reason might be 'wanting to change the world' etc but in the internet advertising space, that is just not going to be the case

3) Friends/Steve Yegge/family potentially regard the company as not a Good Thing to be doing / kind of sketchy. It really is not (although I admit the personal bias) but you may have some awkward conversations

review_title: It's extremely rewarding that the revenue I'm bringing in has a huge impact on our start-ups bottom line!
pros:
- Positive & Collaborative Sales Management to guide you & take your drive to win to a higher level
- What you sell ACTUALLY works in delivering new customers to our clients so you have proof that our technology works for their online advertising campaigns
- If you ask questions of your teammates, they are happy to help & share the buzzwords for verticals & success with other clients
- You will be part of a company that is flipping the traditional advertising model on its' head
cons:
- Branding of our company needs to be improved
- Other teams like operations should have more people to assist w/ the sales team
- the process of getting new clients on board can be improved

pros: There are a lot of smart people working at a lot of good companies, but what has made Quantcast different is the level of genuine cooperation among very talented individuals around common goals. This is much harder said than done. The result is that it's clear what you're working on and why. There is a great sense of purpose and optimism at Quantcast to carry out the company's shared vision. There's a good balance between senior and junior talent.
cons: Quantcast is transitioning from a small to a mid-sized company. There's some legacy that come with that but the management is visible in trying to adapt to the typical cultural and communication challenges that come with that. It's also a fast-growing company which means that there's far more immediate opportunity than resources sometimes allow. Overall, decisions are handled well but does mean having to be creative within constraints.

review_title: Industry-Leading Technology Startup - if you are high-speed, low-drag, you will enjoy working here.
pros: Quantcast is led by a CEO with proven track history of success. The company has retained its relatively flat structure, resulting in approachable management and timely decision-making process. The company has industry-leading technology and continues to grow its intellectual property portfolio. As a startup, there are many opportunities to roll up your sleeves, try different things and work collaboratively with various teams. Individual contributions are transparent/tangible. The engineers are friendly, social and can work well with non-technical staff. Catered lunches and dinners are a definite plus.
cons: Although a secondary factor in accepting a position with the company, salary and benefits are not as competitive as other companies/startups I have worked for. That said, I expect this to change as the company grows and becomes even more profitable. The recruiting team is solid but there is lack of HR presence.
advice_to_mgmt: Information sharing and knowledge transfer will become increasingly important as the company continues to grow at a rapid pace with frequent personnel changes.

review_title: Great work environment: young, friendly, dynamic, highly educated and innovative people
pros:
Quantcast is best for having:
- brilliant minds & expertise
- amazing products
- opportunity to learn from superiors how to deal with professional challenges
- location
- fun (company events, happy hours)
cons: Sometimes, your work has to be delivered on a short term notice, due to the speed with which the changes occur in a start-up environment

review_title: Lots of Energy and Smart People At Quantcast!
pros: Quantcast employs very smart folks. If you are independent and confident employee, you will do well there. There is much opportunity to contribute and gain great experience. Most employees are dedicated and work hard.
cons: Not strong in HR, lack of leadership in HR. Quantcast would do well to add experience and strength here.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue to seek out and hire experienced executives who can lead the teams.

review_title: Cool problems, massive dataset, fun co-workers
pros:
- really big data (we log in excess of 400,000 events per second)
- high growth and innovation (we're rapidly moving into fully real-time computation)
- opportunity to work with very smart people
- plenty of recognition for good work
cons: In terms of your work priorities, you can sometimes be pulled in several directions at once. But then again, it's a small company and still retaining its startup atmosphere, so I think this is to be expected.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue to spur innovation by creating incentives for people to take charge and innovate. Continue to promote inter-term communication

review_title: Quantcast IS All the Great Things About a Start-up!
pros: Quantcast is a fun & energetic place to work. I look forward to coming to work each day. The employees are smart and get along really well. Quantcast puts a lot of effort into keeping its employees positive and happy. The company is dynamic and market-leading. Quantcast takes both change and forward movement very seriously. Senior management has a great depth of experience, and is approachable. Quantcast's CEO is world-class. The company has brilliant prospects. Quantcast is a place where you can learn and grow.
cons: Nothing uncommon for tech start-ups, the hours are long.
advice_to_mgmt: Please continue to listen to all employees, especially those who are the strong but silent type.

review_title: Smart team that is going somewhere
pros:
* Quantcast has done a good job of hiring bright people that are fun to work with.
* The company has a lot of energy
* Bleeding edge technology is used through out the company, and the company has mastered the ability to use it effectively
* The employees are very social
* Challenging and interesting technology projects for engineers
* Truly has the atmosphere of "building something great"
cons:
* Company still has some maturing to do to become "world class"
* Benefits are still light, but stock options are still generous. I would expect this to change as revenue grows.

review_title: You want to work at Quantcast too!
pros:
-coworkers are very intelligent and come from very diverse backgrounds
-company truly cares about the development of its employees- for example training sessions are often held for employees to better understand the products and the roles of each dept
-great work is definitely recognized and praised
-company holds a lot of fun outings
-larger than the typical "startup" but still embraces the innovation aspect; encourages employees to come up with solutions for problems outside of one's usual realm of work
-management team and managers are super excited about the products and definitely true-believers which is extremely encouraging and inspirational
-great management team; very receptive to feedback; open-door policy at all times
-everyone carries their own weight; no slackers
-of course, delicious catered lunch and all-you-drink caffeine
cons: because it is a start up, the lack of processes can be frustrating at times; however, the exec team has been proactive in identifying areas of improvement and a lot of great changes have been/are being implemented

review_title: Fast paced engineering driven workplace at the cutting edge of online targeted advertising in the heart of San Francisco
pros: Quantcast has some of the most technically competent engineers I have ever worked with. This combined with the engineering driven nature of the company and the near flawless execution of its business objectives, makes Quantcast a phenomenal place to work. It is very unusual to find this level of technical caliber north of Palo Alto. With realtime systems processing upward of 400,000 transactions a second and peak data processing at 5 petabytes a day there is never a dull day at Quantcast.
cons: Being a fairly small company, the standard benefits package and yearly compensation are lacking. Also work hours can be long.

review_title: Good people, great executive team and a lot of good food!
pros:
-I really respect the management team here. They like to be involved and are very open.
-The employees here are really direct and like to get things done, but are always having fun doing it
-QC takes really good care of us....Friday funday, food, and there is always some event happening
-The technical problems that QC is tackling are amazingly awesome
-Casual work environment with lots of laughs
cons:
-Not much information is given on growth paths
-Not a ton of promotion within (results of a flat org I guess)
advice_to_mgmt:
Continue to take care of the people that make QC run.

Overall, I think QC is doing a lot of things right....the product is awesome, the Executive team is top notch and everyone is on the same page, and we have a lot of fun.

pros:
- Awesome coworkers
- Interesting technical challenges
- Collaborative atmosphere
- Very fast moving
- Flat organizational structure, approachable execs
- Total meritocracy, plenty of opportunity to make a significant impact and take as much responsibility as you can handle
- Engineering-driven company
- Scooter races
- Beer cart Friday
cons: Dedicated operational support for some teams has been lacking until recently. Dedicated QA support is nonexistent.

review_title: Quantcast is a great place to work at with many interesting problems and really smart people
pros:
Massive amounts of data. Lots of interesting and challenging problems. Fun company to work for right in the middle of downtown San Francisco. Good benefits and salary, free food every day for lunch/dinner. Sometimes we get breakfasts, but don't count on those..

The upper management is generally really motivated, smart, and accessible.
The CEO is awesome.
cons: Office space is a bit crowded. There's also not a lot of incentive to work really hard except for your personal satisfaction (which in my case is enough, but thought I'd put it out there). Interestingly, a lot of people stay long hours.

review_title: Fantastic career growth opportunities with the chance to work with an amazing and tight knit team.
pros: Everyone working here is exceptionally smart and the company is tackling exceptionally ambitious and difficult problems. Quantcast is a collaborative environment with an amazing management team that really cares about the people that work here.
cons: The team has grown a lot recently and the company could use more space in general. The management team has been doing a much better job of communicating strategy to the company lately, they have shown a lot of improvement in this area.

review_title: Quantcast is a dynamic, challenging and exciting place to work and provides endless opportunity to make an impact!
pros: Quantcast is an informal open environment with amazing and approachable senior management. You really get a chance to make an impact here. Most importantly, it is full of very smart and very fun people. It's never boring and every day there is more to learn and greater challenges to achieve.
cons: This is a challenging environment and employees are expected to perform, which means it is sometimes necessary to work overtime.

pros:
-Very encouraging environment.
-Intelligent co-workers.
- Many opportunities to learn new things
-Fun and outgoing co-workers
-Company events and catered meals
-
cons:
-Can feel a little overwhelming at times
-

review_title: Between a Rock and a Digital Space
pros: Free food and cool technology.
cons: Long hours. No one leaves the office. Hard to take vacation.

review_title: smart colleagues, good business opportunity, management issues
pros:
* large lead in sector
* casual / loose / fun workplace culture
* good office location / environment
* strong technology
cons:
* upper management weak on soft skills; too secretive & non-communicative
* poor integration / cooperation between technical & non-technical teams
* non-competitive comp (salary & equity)
advice_to_mgmt:
* pay closer to market rates for talent
* open engineering office on the peninsula to attract geeks who can't commute to SF
* be more open about strategy & results with rank & file

review_title: Great culture, fun place to work, and a lot of very sharp people
pros: Quantcast is a great place to work, with all the standard startup perks (good health care, free lunch, battery powered scooters, etc) and very sharp staff. But the best part is that we are growing fast and really starting to win as a company.
cons: Being pre-IPO, the salaries are a bit low. Maybe higher than other startups but not google or facebook levels. Guess we don't have to commute to Mountain View though.

review_title: It has been a great opportunity to grow within an ambitious and innovation-driven company filled with intelligent people
pros: I think that people come to work at Quantcast because the company gives them the ability to own and work on challenging, substantial problems that clearly have impact. The people that make up the organization are wonderful--smart, approachable, down to earth, and get things done. The opportunities, people, and upside are probably the things that are most rewarding. The idea that you are working on something big and trying to make it big is a constant driving force. It's a relatively small company, which gives people the freedom to "just do things" to solve an abundant set of novel problems.
cons: The company is growing fairly rapidly, so there are still kinks being worked out to balance facilities/amenities with this growth. I think that the way things are improving, this will be a non-issue in time.
advice_to_mgmt: Continue to innovate and drive the status quo, continue to invest in engineering resources, and continue to keep a high standard. Keep people hungry by fostering an environment that rewards hard work and innovation.

pros: Super smart, innovative staff working on huge problems in imaginative ways. The company has found its groove in the past year and has started executing on making itself a very profitable company. Fascinating product. Exec staff is for the most part very approachable and receptive to new ideas. End results, not fluffy strategy, matter most. Great office location in SF.
cons: Culture is improving, but has a bit to go before it is truly a super fun place to work. Engineering focus favors engineering as a solution to most problems.
advice_to_mgmt: Management is doing a better job than in past with acknowledgment and recognition of individual efforts.

review_title: Great team and Challenging place to work
pros:
Very smart people
Challenging Problems
Ability to learn new things
Growth Potential
cons: Ability to work on many different things, sometimes needs prioritization
advice_to_mgmt: Management does a great job, does a good job at communication direction and strategy.

pros: I would say the best reasons to work for Quantcast are big data, smart people, and potential of the company.
cons: You would have to be a work a lot, while having little recognition. You should expect to be pushed around to get things done.
advice_to_mgmt: Employer should pay more attentions to employees' need. While a raise is not always needed, showing that you care about employee happiness is advised.

pros: The atmosphere is friendly, everyone is super nice and supportive, always events to attend that are really interesting and free food is a major bonus!
cons: None that I can think of at all.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep it up, couldn't have asked for a nicer place to work.

pros: Smart motivate colleagues, good management, nice office
cons: General Data Protection Regulation, work life balance

pros:
- Great employees
- Free Food
- Flat hierarchies
cons: Up until now there is nothing bad to say
advice_to_mgmt: I dont have any recommendations to the management. Keep doing what you do.

review_title: Happy Employee Review (positive bias even in the cons)
pros:
Smart people - we're hooked into the London, Bay Area and Seattle tech world. Personally, I feel I've grown as a engineer in my time at Quantcast, directly through engagement with peers (smart people).

Challenging problems - web-scale advertising challenges - 3 billion request per second - 20PB processed a day - how can we do this better than everyone?

Great perks - all meals catered (rare for London), strong social culture (and budget for offsite activities) - Relaxed office culture - access to all the toys AWS has to offer.
cons: Struggling to scale to the next level. Real reasons for this unknown, but from an engineering perspective it seems like we've had 2/3 years of high engineer turnover, particularly in middle level management. That, plus a few weak product decisions. 2018 has seen a big change in engineering and product leadership. Lets see what happens...

review_title: Fantastic Company with a Great Future
pros:
Quantcast is an incredible company. I spent a wonderful 2 years here working with incredibly smart people across the globe.

QC truly allows you to bring your authentic self to work as it relishes diversity. The Dublin office is relatively small with approx 80 people. This intimate nature has inspired a micro culture of fun, and colleagues soon become friends after a few weeks here. QC has all the typical 'tech company' benefits (free lunches/xbox/table tennis etc) which really help in creating the great atmosphere which currently exists.

As a company QC has the worlds largest AI-driven audience behavior platform- that's pretty cool. The company is no longer a start up, and has positioned itself as being a competitive force in a fast paced market.
cons: Not necessarily a 'Con', but Quantcast has brought in a new COO and CRO. Bringing in two senior people at the same time is always a challenge, but both have been a great fit and have already helped set up QC for future success.

pros:
> teams are interesting with very clever people
> a lot of potential for AI and Machine Learning
cons: > London office have less number of girls in tech and a sexual harassment complaints were not taken very seriously
advice_to_mgmt: Need to pay more attention to employees

review_title: Great Culture - Great place to work
pros: Good salaries. The company gives you a lot of opportunities in terms of career growth.
cons: A lot of flexibility is required for such a young company. This is seen as a good thing for people naturally flexible like me but might be seen as a downside by many others.

review_title: You might want to look elsewhere
pros: Some of the best reasons have already left the company. Once a "Best place to work in", this is no longer true.
cons: Multiple rounds of reorganisations, high attrition rate affecting employee morale.
advice_to_mgmt: When you have tried everything and nothing seems to work - perhaps you are the problem.

review_title: A lot of change, but change is good!
pros:
- Amazing people
- Nice office and great location
- Free food
- Good sales incentives
- Some really good managers
- New COO and new strategy
cons:
- product offering isn't as good in all markets
- a lot of change
- communication is a challenge
- marketing is non existent in Europe
advice_to_mgmt:
the new vision is good - better than what we've had in the past - keep working on it and get us all involved in it
figure out career opportunities for every role and level

pros:
I've been with Quantcast for a number of years now and have had a great time working at the company. Having come from much larger organisations, it's been great to see the company grow over this time. Given where the company is at in terms of it's long term strategy and potential IPO, there's obviously challenges along the way but in my experience, that comes with every company no matter the size.
Pros:
Culture - the Dublin culture is 2nd to none and has often been called out by the company as a model to follow. Everyday I get to work with extremely smart, ambitious people who are all pushing for the same goal - no politics here which is great
Product - for any working in advertising, digital or otherwise, you'll get the chance to work on a solution that really does provide value to our customers and compete with the likes of Facebook & Google.
Development - I've had the chance to personally develop both from a skills and career perspective here, and also see others on various teams progress into more senior roles, with some moving into management. I genuinely believe that the things you'll learn here are difficult to come by elsewhere and will stand to anyones long term career.
Benefits - all the standard benefits or working with a Dublin tech company are here, with a regular Friday beer cart always great to bring the teams together.
cons: Like any company our size and aiming for significant growth and IPO, change is an inevitable part of the job. We've seen some shifts in the organisational structure and in executive leadership, all of which will accelerate our growth. In particular new senior hires at CMO & COO level are massive for us.

review_title: Great people on the ground - incompetent exec leadership
pros:
The people you get to work with are in general very friendly, welcoming and generous of their time. There is a base of very talented people.

Excellent relationships with clients and some agencies.

Nicely located offices around the world. Never in the dodgy outskirts, always in the centre near the media agencies and other tech companies.

A good technology base to build from.
cons:
1/ Terrible exec leadership.
CEO is struggling with the job, focusing on details and flying relentlessly for quick local fixes instead of looking at the big picture. The CEO hasn't built a vision of the company and has failed to define what Quantcast should stand for, leaving space for infighting within his team and flavor-of-the-moment company statements. Impossible to rally behind. Every major decision (hires, restructures, investments) has been bad.
SVP of engineering: promotes a very negative culture and no partnership with the Product team. A massive issue for a tech company. Suffocates innovation from junior team members and more senior alike if it doesn't go with what he is thinking.
SVP of Product: very bright but not a product org leader. The quality of the product team and the lack of products (not features) is a testament of that. Needs to build products for the market and abandon the things that none wants.
CMO: chief of buzzwords and no action. A lot of talk, a lot of selfies, a change of colours and logos, shooting ambulances to build his brand, but what is the effect for Quantcast? Where are the positive business outcomes? 90% of his team has churned in less than 6 months. Staff giggles when he is talking at the all hands.

2/ Product not up to scratch
Advertising: Falling behind the competition in terms of results for clients, budget share, consideration and features. Failed to take the mobile turn.
Measurement: will struggle as Google Analytics ups its game and the DMPs become simpler. Will end up being a quick fix solution for small, spammy websites.
Data: the cornerstone of Quantcast's position is that it sees users hundred's of times of month. But according to the internal analysts, this is a lie. And more stringent privacy laws around the world + tracking blocks will put an end to this.

3/ Vision
Where is it?

4/ Spirit
Most employees are looking around.
None challenges the leadership or senior management.
Employees internally are making fun of the leadership and the company positioning (the recent shift to AI was perceived as a farce and is the subject of endless memes)
advice_to_mgmt: All except the new COO (who I haven't worked with): please allow for a new and different set of leaders to come and save the company.

review_title: Looks slick from the outside, but chaotic and frustrating in reality
pros:
Some nice people work here.

The tech was exciting back in 2014.

Free lunches.

Everyone got a free Amazon Echo to distract us from the reality of the situation.

Work life balance is good because most people no longer see the upside of overworking themselves when another restructure is on the horozon.
cons:
Redundancies & attrition - company performance is very poor, but to tackle this, they've decided to let a number of quality, experienced people go in all offices and departments. The brain drain at all levels and departments is severe. A lot of senior product, marketing, operations and engineering people have moved on and not been replaced.

Poor leadership - at all levels. From the CEO who has overseen every bad decision in recent years, to shockingly poor middle management. Management is only interested in managing up unfortunately. Very few people have been promoted from within and they are usually bad choices.

Salary and package is not competitive. The company does compete with Google/Facebook/LinkedIn for comparable roles. As a result, questionable hires are made as the truly great people go to those companies instead.

Game of Thrones (executive edition) - a fun game to play is to look at the leadership page on the UK site, and compare it to the leadership page on the US site. Oh look, there's a VP of Engineering on the UK site, but not the US site. That's another casualty in unending turnover in executive leadership. I love that they fire members of the leadership teams but forget to remove them from the international sites. There is constant turmoil at the top and this filters down in various manners of unpleasantness as the average workers deal with the fallout of yet another restructure initiated by a bruised ego.

Questionable positioning - oh hey, we're an "AI" company now. We were a programmatic/machine learning/RTB company over the past 10 years. Interesting that the new CMO shows up, throws his favourite marketing buzzwords into the mix and that's our direction now. Does no-one else see that the CMO is busier promoting himself instead of the company? A rebrand is the lowest of the low hanging fruit and an easy win for him.

Learning & Development - forget about it. There is nothing happening on that front. Unless you are very junior, you will learn nothing to add to your experience. All new experience and skills are hired externally. Be very careful about joining Quantcast as an experienced hire, unless you are excellent at political game playing.

Stagnant product - has not been updated in many years. The market has passed the company by and QC has done nothing to address concerns around transparency, pricing, margins, brand safety and also nothing in adapting product suitability for the markets in which it is sold. This is worse in EMEA than in the US.

Promotion process - it's painful. Too many times, good people are passed over and instead they promote the unqualified person that was friends with a manager in their old company. It ends up in a cross departmental political shouting match where managers from one department shout down the promotion choices of another department. Absolutely infuriating.

Workflows and restructures - daily workflow is not clear and changes all the time. Entire departments have been in a constant state of re-organisation for years so the goalposts are constantly shifting. This is not a stable company.

Changing the company focus - the old products may as well be dead as the focus of the company is shifting to something else. That means all remaining resources are working on this new vision and all the existing products are likely to stagnate further.
advice_to_mgmt:
Where do you even start? The only sensible course of action is to place the current CEO in a figurehead role and employ a leader with a proven track record to bring this company to the next level. The employees that have toiled away for years deserve a chance at converting their moribund stock options into something valuable at some point.

Also - it has been said repeatedly, but there needs to be a true evaluation of learning requirements and budget should be required to upskilling the people that are worth retaining.

Finally, management at all levels requires evaluation. There are people in management who are embarrassingly lacking in skills, execution and vision. This has been the case for many years.
