pros:
The Dublin office is very well located. It comes with the usual perks that you now see in high tech companies : flexible workspaces, breakfast and lunch, yoga classes...

The technology is very impressive and there is a lot to wow your customers. If you want to get into real time advertising, Quantcast is very advanced. However the strategy for growth renders the quality of the solution completely pointless.

The sales methodology and sales training is excellent. If only the sales team and the managers put that into real practice instead of just repeating the keywords like parrots!
cons:
Quantcast has a bad track record when it comes to managing people. I had seen negative reviews before I joined, and I heard negative feedback from my personal network including recruiting agencies. The team I interviewed with for sales convinced me it would be just fine. Little did I know that it was going to be such a mess.

Here's what I struggled with:
- Don't get fooled by the titles! A sales manager is in reality an account executive in charge of new business.
- Inexperienced managers who have never worked outside of Ireland but need to cover areas like DACH, Southern Europe or Israel and have no clue
- No territory policy : I ran a report in Salesforce which showed me that just before someone joins the company, the other AEs put the "juicy" accounts under their name and sit on them just by principle.
- This means that new people are not allocated a fair and relevant patch, and are left with either cold accounts or accounts with no budget.
- This also means that sales people are fighting for the same accounts and it fosters a culture of mistrust.
- Managers refuse to discuss the territory issues and will beat you on the head about your quotas even though you have a dry patch.
- If you join as an AE, you may eventually be promoted to senior AE, but after that it's limbo. Teams are too small to require more managers, and there is no career path to a field role.

Since I left, the SDR programme seems to have been scrapped. some markets have been closed down and a large number of people in leadership roles have left (voluntarily or not).

When it comes to people, everyone is smart and capable. But here's very little recognition from managers: they put more value on someone who's been in the company for 15 months than on someone who brings more sales experience. It's very difficult to change the way things are done, however hard the sales enablement team tries (and God knows they try and they're good).

Cases of bullying are frequent. Usually brushed under the carpet. It's particularly true in the local offices in continental Europe.

Commissions are not calculated on the amount of the deal you closed. They're calculated based on the budget invoiced to the customer and paid on a quarterly basis in the following quarter. EX: your Q1 commissions (Jan to March) will be paid in May. Bear that in mind.

HR is a joke with no insight into what people do, no exit interview for terminated contracts, and an apparent disregard for churn. They seem to live under the delusion that there are hundreds of candidates queuing at the door.
advice_to_mgmt:
Wake up: your reputation in Dublin is horrible and everyone knows it. There are so many horror stories about Quantcast that not only will you lose employees but also clients. Clients read Glassdoor too.

Clarify what career evolutions are available or not and what are the criteria. Don't hide behind fake reasons.

Stop using the "start up" excuses. The company is 11 years old. Hire business people to take it out of the slump or sell it to the competition.

You have a wonderful technology and the best people at engineering, campaign analysis and CS levels. Make the sales organisation work properly and you'll improve all the KPIs.

While standing at just over 900 people worldwide, the Dublin office in particular still has a great start-up vibe with small teams.

You are surrounded by incredibly smart and driven people. Quantcast has attracted the people in the tech community who do not want to be another little cog in a big wheel. They have joined to make an impact, to be a part of something bigger.

Due to the size of the org; you have the opp to have a lot of exposure to aspects of the business and the senior leaders themselves, that you typically wouldn't expect to have.

Culture focused; everyone is very focused on keeping a great culture in Quantcast; from the infamous "beer cart" to monthly off-sites and new hire inductions, there is a big push on fun, inclusion and diversity. We celebrate different cultures, ideas and thoughts and regularly push internal and external events to drive awareness of these.

You're well looked after in terms of food, onsite perks, office off sites and nights out and the office itself is really nice. Work hard, play hard is exactly what happens here.
cons:
Typical challenges facing a pre-ipo company with a relatively flat org structure; a lot of self-managed teams, who work with a lot of responsibility on their shoulders.

You work hard in Quantcast, which can sometimes involve putting in extra time when needed.
advice_to_mgmt: Listen to your team and keep them as informed as possible!

pros:
* First, please note that the recent burst of high ratings is due to internal recruiters asking employees to rate quantcast. That doesn't mean they're lying, but keep that in mind.
* coworkers are great and hiring standards are high
* if you're on the right team, you do legitimately work on big data / hadoop. None of the 16 node "clusters" that other companies claim; we use 1k+ node clusters on 100+ TB datasets.
* quantcast, as a company, is performing well
* the display ad space is growing and quantcast is on the cutting edge of the rtb market
* the ceo Konrad and the head of product Jag are very impressive people who do great work. In fact the majority of the employees are great at their jobs, but Konrad and Jag stand out.

so, should you work here?
* if you'll be working on hadoop jobs, probably: you'll get a great practical education in parallel computing and a great chit on your resume
* it depends on the team; make sure you aren't one of the people talking to salesforce or writing etl logic
* financially it won't make you rich even if quantcast goes public, but you may learn a lot more here on the right team
cons:
* what you work on and how good the job is can vary quite wildly by team. Our ops team is massively overworked and seems to burn out within 6 months and either quit or transfer, while other teams have great retention.
* some people do write massive hadoop jobs, but you might end up coding interface / workflow logic to interface with salesforce or an ad server. This is neither interesting nor exciting.
* It's fair to say there are very exciting and interesting technologies being built inside quantcast, but the important question is if you will be working on them.
* though it varies by team, it's fair to say that managers take little interest in career development of employees.
* someone below claimed stock options are generous. That's simply wrong. Engineers hired now will get a stock option package that pays out roughly $120k after taxes per billion dollars earned in a liquidity event if fully vested. Financially, you're probably better off going to Google. Upper management also seems to massively overestimate the value of stock options and we've had a ton of turnover of people who made quantcast a worse company for leaving.
* most importantly... more than 1/2 the company has quit in the last 16 months since our previous employee photo. Including the cto who is an amazing technologist. Management rarely discusses this with employees and doesn't seem to care to retain people. This is worst in the engineering department through true across the company. To quantcast's credit, when engineers quit I was almost always really sad to see the person leave. The majority were definitely not bad hires. Plus, with our internal hadoop variant there is an enormous learning curve for engineers and it really hurts when people who understand all the internal systems keep leaving.
* the only direct effort to increase retainment is by moving salary to bonus and not paying it out until late April so that if an employee leaves before then he or she effectively forfeits 10% of his or her salary for the previous year.
advice_to_mgmt:
* Figure out why good employees keep leaving and fix some of the issues.
* Take an interest in employee career development. If an employee's manager can't name what an employee wants to do in his or her career and isn't figuring out how to help that person get there the manager isn't doing his or her job.

review_title: This is a highly innovative company that thrives on harnessing peoples' talents in a non-bureacratic, open-minded manner
pros: Hiring standards are high, factoring in individual maturity & ability to collaborate and problem solve. Core competencies: modeling & data mining on huge data sets, a super fast reliable computing platform, and real time bidding platform. Great, well trained corporate sales force.
cons: Could bt more transparent in information sharing among employees--getting better though. Will need more processes as it scales.

review_title: Awesome environment, filled with talented people who are always willing to pitch in.
pros: Quantcast is an amazing company to work for. The organization is filled with dedicated, talented and creative employees who are passionate for what they do. Everyone is willing to lend a hand to help you achieve your goals. Communication is really special and you have access to anyone anytime.
cons: There is very little room for improvement. Quantcast is constantly trying to look at new ways to improve the work/life balance.
advice_to_mgmt: Get the brand exposed more as a media play and not just an analytics company. It would be great to see a lead gen display campaign.

review_title: Great place to learn and grow -- Phenomenal opportunity to absorb the perks of the dot com era minus the risk
pros:
*Free food - who doesn't love that?
*Friday Happy Hour with beer/wine & creative snacks that seem to change weekly!
*Creative ff-site events including Dodge Ball, Giants games, Bowling, too! QC prioritizes fun!
*Innovative brainiac employees who work hard and play even harder.
cons:
*Occasionally difficult to schedule time off due to work load
*Stronger HR presence needed

review_title: Challenging and extremely rewarding so far.
pros: Huge opportunities for innovation. Diverse, extremely smart and hard working engineering teams. Phenomenal technology being built.
cons: Sometimes overly complex technology and not much cross-talk between teams building different products, though these are areas we're constantly working to improve on.

review_title: a REAL start-up...if you can handle it.
pros: smart company, and true industry leaders. You have to come with an open mind, as you will walk in to a room with people much smarter than the industry at large (even if you come from the digital space!). Ambitious company with big plans make this place fun and challenging. It is great walking into a company that truly changes the "old" way of doing business. CHECK YOUR EGO AT THE DOOR! The nice thing with Quantcast is that the technology is strong, there is a true long term vision. To sell a product that is industry leading is wonderful.
cons: As most companies that are growing fast, there are your occasional hiccups and missteps.

review_title: Somewhat stressful work environment with a lot of upside
pros: Very rewarding set of problems. Great potential upside. Has become a much more enjoyable place to work in the last year. Awesome CEO.
cons: The place is at times stressful and they've been occasionally brutal with firings but generally the place is very fair.

pros: Sehr gutes Gesamtpaket aus Fixgehalt, Bonus, Aktienoptionen und sonstigen Vorteilen wie bspw. Verpflegung vor Ort im Büro.
cons: Die Strategie des Unternehmens wird häufig geändert und nicht klar kommuniziert. Die Vision und die Ziele sind bekannt, aber bei der Erreichung ist man auf sich gestellt.
advice_to_mgmt: Mitarbeitern das Gefühl geben, in Entscheidungen einbezogen zu werden und dabei mitzuwirken ist sehr wichtig für die Motivation.
